channel.title: BBC News - Europe
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: France teacher attack: Four pupils held over beheading
item.description: In all, 15 people are now in custody after the murder of teacher Samuel Paty near Paris.

item.title: Coronavirus: Republic of Ireland to move to highest restrictions
item.description: The new rules, broadly similar to the spring lockdown, are due to last for six weeks.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Russian hackers targeted Games, UK says
item.description: UK officials say Russian intelligence took aim at the 2020 Olympics before they were delayed.

item.title: Coronavirus: Germany improves ventilation to chase away Covid
item.description: Public buildings receive €500m of German state cash to improve ventilation systems.

item.title: Coronavirus: Belgium facing 'tsunami' of new infections
item.description: The country is close to being overwhelmed as the number of cases soars, the health minister warns.

item.title: Brexit: UK calls for change as EU makes trade talks pledge
item.description: No 10 says there is "no basis to resume talks" without changes, after the EU offers to "intensify" talks.

item.title: Bank boss: UK facing 'unprecedented economic uncertainty'
item.description: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey warns there is significant risk of lower economic growth.

item.title: Wild boar family killed by police in Rome children's playground
item.description: The city's mayor orders an investigation amid outrage from residents and animal rights groups.

item.title: Northern Cyprus: Right-wing nationalist Ersin Tatar elected president
item.description: Ersin Tatar, who is pro-Turkey and wants Cyprus to be two separate states, is elected president.

item.title: EU investigates Instagram over handling of children's data
item.description: Facebook could face a large fine if Instagram is found to have broken European Union privacy laws.

item.title: Young child among migrants crossing the English Channel
item.description: Dozens of people make the crossing in small boats as winds increase in the English Channel.

item.title: Firms urged to get ready for new EU relationship
item.description: The government campaign says "Time is running out", but firms say many unanswered questions remain.

item.title: Samuel Paty: Beheading of teacher deepens divisions over France's secular identity
item.description: Mass rallies over the murder of a teacher mask growing dissent over the country's secular identity.

item.title: Bletchley Park’s contribution to WW2 'over-rated'
item.description: The code-breaking hub is not "the war winner" many people think it is, says a history of spy agency GCHQ.

item.title: Sleeping giants to host Messi and Ronaldo
item.description: Ferencvaros, once one of Europe's most revered sides, are the sleeping giants set to welcome Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo.

item.title: Portugal's radical move to decriminalise all drugs
item.description: How Portugal became the first country to decriminalise all drugs for personal use

item.title: Viewpoint: Why Turkey is flexing its muscles abroad
item.description: Turkey's engagement in the Southern Caucasus is only the latest venture in a tougher foreign policy.

item.title: Lesbos: What really happened in the refugee camp destroyed by flames?
item.description: BBC Newsnight looks into the origins of the fire that destroyed Europe's largest refugee camp.

item.title: Germany pulls fresh air into fight against Covid
item.description: The German government is investing heavily in air purifiers to help curb the spread of coronavirus.

item.title: Is sainthood on the cards for a computer programmer?
item.description: A computer programmer’s beatification could lead to the world’s first millennial saint.

item.title: Azerbaijan at war: Reporter’s journal
item.description: A BBC team spent a week looking at the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict from the Azerbaijani side.

item.title: Covid-19: Is Sweden getting it right?
item.description: The BBC's Ros Atkins looks at one country that has been an outlier from the start of the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: Dutch drinkers party before new Covid rules kick in
item.description: Hospitality industry put under stricter coronavirus rules in the Netherlands.
